author: SteveL-MSFT
body:
Fixed error message using a null resourcemanager
With most recent CoreFx supporting STA, removed special CoreClr code paths
Added test coverage
Removed some dead commented out code that was never used

Part of https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/4158

Fix https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/3353

If you are a PowerShell Team member, please make sure you choose the Reviewer(s) and Assignee for your PR.
If you are not from the PowerShell Team, you can leave the fields blank and the Maintainers will choose them for you. If you are familiar with the team, feel free to mention some Reviewers yourself.

For more information about the roles of Reviewer and Assignee, refer to CONTRIBUTING.md.

-->

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: CI failure is due to one of the same failures in the nightly run unrelated to this PR.  I'll fix that first.

comments.author: adityapatwardhan
comments.body: @mirichmo Can you rebase, it should fix the test failures.

comments.author: mirichmo
comments.body: All the CredSSP tests are now passing in AppVeyor and Travis.

comments.author: ltamaster
comments.body: Hi All, I was looking to use the WSManCredSSP functionalities. has this PR enabled in a release? I checked the v6.0.0-beta.6 because it mentions that it was added, but it didn't work for me. Thanks Luis

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @ltamaster CredSSP is only supported on Windows

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
@SteveL-MSFT It seems PowerShell docs haven't  "Supported platforms: Windows, Linux, MacOS" in cmdlet's descriptions. 
Also we could make the error message more clear: "The term `Cmdlet` is _not supported_ on the platform or is not recognized ..."

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
@iSazonov can you point me to the docs that say it's supported on Linux/macOS?  Don't see that line [here](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Docs/blob/717336cea2cc4a3c7f6c100a4330256a27823331/reference/6/Microsoft.WSMan.Management/Enable-WSManCredSSP.md)

I think the error message is technically correct as that cmdlet doesn't exist on non-Windows.  It's a generic error message if a cmdlet is not found, so implying it's `not supported` may cause confusion particularly for typos.

comments.author: iSazonov

title: Enable WSManCredSSP cmdlets
